title: POLICY: No Silent Test Skipping - Tests Must Run or Mock
description:
**CRITICAL TESTING POLICY**

Tests must NEVER silently skip or short-circuit based on environment variables or missing dependencies. Every test must either:

1. **RUN** - Execute with real or mocked dependencies
2. **FAIL LOUDLY** - Raise clear assertion error if prerequisites missing
3. **MOCK** - Use mock objects when real services unavailable

**FORBIDDEN PATTERNS:**
- `if not os.getenv("X"): return` (silent skip)
- Module-level imports that raise on missing env vars (blocks test collection)
- `@unittest.skipIf/skipUnless` without CI-compatible fallback
- Tests that pass trivially when env var is unset

**REQUIRED PATTERNS:**
- `TESTING=true` should enable mock mode for all external services
- Test collection must NEVER fail due to env vars
- All tests must run in CI without special env vars beyond TESTING=true

**Why This Matters:**
- CI passes falsely when tests are skipped
- Bugs slip through because code paths never execute
- Developers think tests pass when they actually didn't run

title: Cerebras tool-loop responses missing headers/planning block (malformed JSON)
description:
Context: After PR #2353, Cerebras models (e.g., zai-glm-4.6) sometimes return malformed/incomplete JSON; parser recovers only some fields, so session_header and planning_block go missing. Planning-block fallback was removed, so missing headers/blocks surface.

Updated requirements (per latest direction):
- First inference call should mirror origin/main: plain JSON mode, with schema expectations (session_header, planning_block, etc.) and only optional tools available. The model should produce the full schema in the first call unless it explicitly needs tools.
- Only perform a second call if the model returns tool_calls; then execute tools and send results in a follow-up JSON-mode call (tools disabled).
- Do not rely on regex salvage for planning_block; rely on the schema. If the first/second response is missing session_header/planning_block, reprompt once with a short "add missing fields" request or inject a minimal default.
- Make planning_block/session_header schema compliance primary; salvage is last resort.

Artifacts: flask-server.log 2025-12-12 11:30:46–51 for campaign VqqJLpABua9bvAG4ArTg, provider cerebras/model zai-glm-4.6.

Requested work:
1) Adjust Cerebras (and other providers if needed) to a tool-on-demand flow (first call JSON sans tools; tools only if requested), aligning with origin/main behavior.
2) Add a one-time reprompt/default insertion when session_header/planning_block is missing after the final response.
3) Replace regex-based planning_block extraction with a robust/bracket-aware method if salvage is still kept as a last resort.
notes: Add mitigations: when Cerebras tool-loop responses are malformed and missing session_header/planning_block, reprompt or inject a minimal default instead of accepting partial JSON. Capture raw response for debugging. Restart server after constants changes to ensure tool-loop path is used.

title: Native tools forced on non-tool models returns 400
description: After PR #2353 the providers force native tool-calling with tool_choice='required' for all Cerebras/OpenRouter models. Models that do not support function-calling (e.g., Cerebras gpt-oss-120b, llama-3.3-70b; some OpenRouter models) now respond 400 before story generation, blocking users who pick those models. Fix by gating tool_choice/tools to models that support tools or falling back to JSON-only flow when unsupported.
notes:
**UPDATE 2025-12-17:** Web research shows both gpt-oss-120b and llama-3.3-70b DO support tool calling on Cerebras.

However, llama-3.3-70b has a MULTI-TURN LIMITATION: "Multi-turn tool calling is currently not supported with the llama-3.3-70b model. This model will error if you include a non-empty tool_calls array on an assistant turn."

**Root cause hypothesis:** Our two-phase flow may be including previous tool_calls in conversation history, triggering the multi-turn error on llama-3.3-70b.

**Fix options:**
1. Clear tool_calls from history before Phase 2 for llama-3.3-70b
2. Use single-turn pattern for affected models
3. NOT an allowlist issue - models DO support tools

Sources: https://inference-docs.cerebras.ai/capabilities/tool-use

title: Tool-on-demand LLM entrypoint (reduce malformed JSON, restore headers/blocks)
description:
Goal: Align with origin/main by making the first LLM call plain JSON (no tools) and only doing a second call if tool_calls are returned.

Problem: Current tool-loop entrypoint (PR #2353) sends tool-enabled first calls for Cerebras/OR and Gemini 2.x. Some providers (e.g., Cerebras) return malformed/partial JSON with missing session_header/planning_block on non-dice turns. Fallback was removed, so headers/blocks go missing.

Proposed approach:
1) First call: JSON mode, no tools; brief instruction tells the model to request tool calls if dice/skills/saves needed.
2) If tool_calls present: execute tools, then second call JSON mode (tools disabled) with results to produce final structured response.
3) If no tool_calls: use first response as final.
4) Fallback: if session_header or planning_block missing after final response, reprompt once to add them. Keep malformed-JSON salvage as last resort.

Scope/files:
- mvp_site/llm_service.py: adjust dispatch to tool-on-demand.
- mvp_site/llm_providers/*: ensure plain JSON helper; tool loop only when tool_calls exist.
- Prompts: instruct models to request tools when needed; no “tools always” assumption.

Acceptance:
- Non-dice turns complete in one call with session_header + planning_block present.
- Dice turns complete in two calls with executed tool results and valid JSON.
- Reduced malformed-JSON incidence for Cerebras/OR; missing headers/blocks covered by reprompt fallback.

title: Harden narrative/XP/time validation and fuzzy JSON extraction
description:
Summary of investigation findings:
1) Narrative truncation: malformed JSON when narrative contains unescaped quotes; parser truncates mid-sentence. Need fuzzy extraction fallback to capture full narrative when strict parse fails or length is suspiciously short.
2) Level/XP discrepancies: prompts in mechanics_system_instruction were vague ("typically double" XP); game_state blindly accepts LLM XP/level. Need to enforce D&D 5e XP table in prompt and add validation in GameState (_validate_level_consistency) to warn on mismatches.
3) Time tracking anomalies: GameState accepts backward time jumps. Add validate_time_monotonicity to detect/reject/warn when new timestamp < previous.

Updated leveling approach:
- Backend owns XP→level (and level→XP) using the fixed 5e table; LLM does not compute level. If LLM proposes mismatched XP/level, backend corrects or reprompts.
- Prompt change: tell the LLM "XP/level are authoritative from the system; do not change them. When you mention level or XP, use the provided values." LLM may propose "apply level-up now" flags, but backend applies the table and updates state.

Requested work:
- Add robust fallback extraction in narrative_response_schema.py for malformed JSON.
- Update mechanics_system_instruction.md to include standard 5e cumulative XP table and remove ambiguous guidance; include the prompt text above about authoritative XP/level.
- Implement GameState validation hooks: level/XP consistency (auto-correct or warn) and time monotonicity (warn/reject backwards time).

title: Implement Native Two-Phase Tool Calling for All Non-Gemini Models
description:
Replace prompt-based tool_requests approach with native API tool calling for Cerebras/OpenRouter providers.

## Problem
- Current approach uses JSON schema with `tool_requests` field via prompt instructions
- GLM-4.6 and other models ignore this because they're trained for native tool calling
- API limitation: `tools` + `response_format` cannot be used together

## Solution
Implement true two-phase native tool calling:
- Phase 1: `tools` parameter (no JSON schema) → get `tool_calls` in response
- Phase 2: `response_format` parameter (no tools) → get structured JSON with results

## Scope
- Gemini 2.0/3.0: Keep single-phase code_execution (supports both together)
- Gemini 2.5: Native two-phase
- All Cerebras: Native two-phase  
- All OpenRouter: Native two-phase
design:
## Architecture

### Strategy Selection (constants.py)
```python
def get_dice_roll_strategy(model_name, provider):
    if model_name in {"gemini-2.0-flash", "gemini-3-pro-preview"}:
        return "code_execution"  # Single phase
    return "native_two_phase"  # All others
```

### Native Two-Phase Flow
1. Phase 1: Call with `tools=DICE_ROLL_TOOLS`, no response_format
2. Extract `tool_calls` from response.choices[0].message.tool_calls
3. Execute tools using execute_dice_tool()
4. Phase 2: Call with `response_format=JSON_SCHEMA`, include tool results as message

### Files to Modify
- constants.py: Simplify get_dice_roll_strategy()
- cerebras_provider.py: Add generate_content_with_native_tools()
- openrouter_provider.py: Add generate_content_with_native_tools()
- gemini_provider.py: Add native_two_phase for 2.5
- llm_service.py: Route to correct strategy
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] All Cerebras models use native tool calling
- [ ] All OpenRouter models use native tool calling
- [ ] Gemini 2.0/3.0 keep single-phase code_execution
- [ ] Gemini 2.5 uses native two-phase
- [ ] GLM-4.6 produces dice rolls in combat
- [ ] Smoke tests pass for all providers
- [ ] No regression in existing functionality
notes:
Implementation complete. All providers updated to use native two-phase tool calling:
- constants.py: Simplified get_dice_roll_strategy() to return only code_execution or native_two_phase
- cerebras_provider.py: Added generate_content_with_native_tools()
- openrouter_provider.py: Added generate_content_with_native_tools()  
- gemini_provider.py: Added generate_content_with_native_tools() for Gemini 2.5
- llm_service.py: Updated routing to use correct strategies
- test_code_execution_dice_rolls.py: Updated tests for new architecture

50 tests passing. Needs smoke test validation with live APIs to confirm GLM-4.6 produces dice rolls.

title: NPC death state not persisting (Marcus elimination issue)
description:
NPC death state not persisting between turns. User kills Marcus but game still presents options to kill him.

ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS (CONFIRMED):

**TWO SEPARATE ISSUES:**

1. **apply_automatic_combat_cleanup NOT called in main story flow**
   - world_logic.py line 905: `update_state_with_changes` called
   - NO `apply_automatic_combat_cleanup` call after it
   - Cleanup only called in GOD_MODE flows (lines 1817, 1887)
   - Result: combat_state HP=0 deaths are not synced to npc_data

2. **cleanup_defeated_enemies DELETES instead of marking dead**
   - game_state.py line 729: `del self.npc_data[enemy_name]`
   - For generic enemies (goblins): deletion is correct
   - For named NPCs (Marcus): need `status: ["dead"]` to persist
   - Without status, LLM can't know NPC is dead

**WHY THIS HAPPENS:**
- npc_data EXCLUDED from LLM context (to save tokens - ~500/NPC)
- entity_tracking_data is READ-ONLY trimmed data
- LLM can't see death status → offers to kill dead NPCs

**FIX REQUIRED:**
1. Add `apply_automatic_combat_cleanup` call after line 905 in main story flow
2. Modify cleanup to mark named NPCs as dead instead of deleting
acceptance_criteria:
- NPC deaths update npc_data.status = 'dead'
- Dead NPCs not offered as targets in planning blocks
- State persists across sessions
notes: Traced to commit ded8efa84 which excluded npc_data from context. Cleanup function exists but is not called in main flow. This is a pre-existing bug on origin/main, not from PR #2353.

title: Optimize Cerebras: Skip Phase 2 when no tool_calls with fallback
description: Implement conditional Phase 2 skip for Cerebras to reduce latency when tools aren't needed, while maintaining schema enforcement as fallback.
design:
## Problem
Current Cerebras implementation always runs Phase 2 for schema enforcement, even when Phase 1 returns no tool_calls and valid JSON text.

## Solution
Conditionally skip Phase 2 when safe, with fallback to schema enforcement:

```
Phase 1 (tools + text generation)
    ↓
Has tool_calls? ─Yes→ Execute tools → Phase 2 (with schema)
    │
    No
    ↓
Try parse text as JSON
    ↓
Valid + matches schema? ─Yes→ Use directly (skip Phase 2)
    │
    No
    ↓
Phase 2 (with schema enforcement)
```

## Benefits
- Single-call for non-tool turns (majority of LLM calls)
- Schema enforcement preserved as safety net
- No risk of malformed JSON reaching game state

## Implementation Notes
- Add JSON schema validation utility
- Track metrics: Phase 2 skip rate, fallback rate
- Consider feature flag for gradual rollout
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Phase 1 text is parsed as JSON when no tool_calls
- [ ] Schema validation runs on parsed JSON
- [ ] Valid JSON skips Phase 2 call
- [ ] Invalid JSON falls back to Phase 2
- [ ] Metrics track skip/fallback rates
- [ ] No regression in response quality
- [ ] Latency improvement measured

title: BUG: clock_skew_credentials.py blocks test collection on import
description:
**Problem:**
`world_logic.py` imports `clock_skew_credentials` and calls `apply_clock_skew_patch()` at module level (line 35). This triggers `validate_deployment_config()` which raises `ValueError` if `WORLDAI_GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS` is set without `WORLDAI_DEV_MODE=true`.

**Impact:**
- Test collection fails for any test that imports `world_logic`
- CI "passes" because CI doesn't have the env var - tests never run
- Local devs with service account keys cannot run tests without setting extra env vars

**Files Affected:**
- `mvp_site/clock_skew_credentials.py:40-44` - The raising code
- `mvp_site/world_logic.py:35` - Module-level call to `apply_clock_skew_patch()`
- `mvp_site/tests/test_game_state.py:88` - Import fails here

**Root Cause:**
Validation logic runs at import time, not runtime. This is a design flaw - module imports should NEVER raise based on env vars.

**Fix Required:**
1. Make `validate_deployment_config()` return status, not raise
2. OR defer validation until actual Firebase operation
3. OR respect `TESTING=true` to skip validation entirely
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Tests can be collected without WORLDAI_DEV_MODE
- [ ] TESTING=true bypasses clock skew validation
- [ ] test_game_state.py runs in CI
- [ ] Local devs can run tests with service account keys
